name: Cheryl Maas
special_notes: Same-sex partner of Stine Brun Kjeldaas

name: Jan Herzog
description: German rower Jan Herzog placed 11th with the coxless fours at the 2000 Sydney Olympics and sixth partnering Tobias Kühne in the coxless pairs at the 2004 Athens Games. In 2008, Herzog won the University Boat Race representing Oxford. Internationally, he won a bronze medal with the lightweight coxed fours at the 1997 World Championships, and in 1999, won the Grand Challenge Cup at the Henley Royal Regatta. Herzog was a cousin of non-Olympian rowers Joel and Irady El-Qalqili. The latter married Kerstin Kowalski. At German nationals, Herzog won the coxless pairs title in 2001 and 2003-04, the coxed pairs in 2004, and the eights in 1999. He also won the lightweight coxless fours and the eights titles, both in 1997.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Competed in the Boat Race (2008 Oxford (won))

name: Reginald Douglas
description: Reginald Douglas had the following podium finishes at major championships: 1st in the 1954 British Empire and Commonwealth Games Coxless Pairs, 1st in the 1958 British Empire and Commonwealth Games Coxless Pairs, 2nd in the 1954 British Empire and Commonwealth Games Double Sculls. In all three competitions he was partnered with Bob Parker).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (2–1–0 1954 Vancouver ROW gold: coxless pairs, silver: double sculls; 1958 Cardiff ROW gold: coxless pairs)

special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Mediterranean Games (1–1–0 1997 Bari ATH gold: marathon; 2001 Tunis ATH silver: marathon)

name: Karl Hofstetter
description: Karl Hofstetter played for HC Olten in the 1950s, and received his first international cap in 1951 for a match against Austria. He was selected in 1952 for the Swiss Olympic team alongside clubmate Erich Funk, where the Swiss team placed 9th. Hofstetter won a Swiss championship title with HC Olten in 1952.

name: Abbe Jansson
description: Abbe Jansson is little known but deserves some measure of fame. Prior to playing goalie at the 1920 Antwerpen Olympics, he practiced with a fencing mask, and became the first international hockey goaltender to wear a mask. Jansson also won a gold medal at the 1923 European Championships. Jansson played in Belgium with Brussels IHC from 1920-23. He was with Göta IK in Stockholm in 1925-27 and 1929-32. In 1927/28 he played again with Brussels IHC and also with Lidingo IF, and then stayed with Lidingo in the 1928/29 season. Jansson later became a hockey consultant in Göteborg.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Ice Hockey Championships (1–0–0 1923 Antwerpen gold)

name: Barbie Harwerth
description: Barbie Harwerth attended the Incarnate Word College in San Antonio, Texas. A Texas native, she played for St. Cecilia’s Club in San Antonio. After college Harwerth married, becoming Barbie Navia, and worked as a teacher. Her daughter, Annalise Navia, played volleyball at the University of Memphis.

name: La Moine Batson
description: Lemoine Batson began competing in ski jumping as early as 1917. After competing in the 1924 Winter Olympics, he was later selected for the 1932 USA Olympic team as a ski jumper, but did not compete. His best jump was one of 183 feet in Westby, Wisconsin in 1925, equaling the hill record. He later became a sports administrator, and was the first chairman of the Central US Ski Association, serving as its president in 1939-40.

name: Drew McMaster
description: Personal Best: 100 – 10.34 (1983).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (1–0–1 1978 Edmonton ATH gold: 4×100 m relay (competed for Scotland); 1982 Brisbane ATH bronze: 4×100 m relay (competed for Scotland))

name: Eleanor Haslam
description: Eleanor Haslam had the following podium finishes at major championships: 3rd in the 1958 British Empire and Commonwealth Games 4×110 yards Relay (with Diane Matheson, Maureen Rever, and the non-Olympian Freyda Berman). Haslam also finished sixth in the 220 yards and was eliminated in the heats of the 100 yards at the 1958 British Empire and Commonwealth Games. Personal Bests: 100 – 11.9 (1956); 200 – 24.12y (1958); 800 – 2:10.0 (1960).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (0–0–1 1958 Cardiff ATH bronze: 4×110 yards relay)

name: Anne Poleska
description: German breaststroke swimmer Anne Poleska, later the wife of German rower Jochen Urban, won the 200 metres bronze medal at the 2004 Athens Olympics, but missed the finals at Sydney in 2000 and Beijing in 2008. At the 2005 World Championships she had her greatest moment when winning the silver medal. Poleska was awarded the Silver Bay Leaf, Germany’s highest sports award. At European Championships she won the silver medal in 2002, and two gold medals at the 2004 and 2005 European Short-Course Championships. Poleska also won two more silvers in 2003 and 2006, and two bronze medals in 2002 and 2007, all in the 200 metres breast. She also won 14 German national titles.
special_notes: Wife of Jochen Urban Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (0–1–0 2001 Beijing SWI silver: 200 m breaststroke) Listed in Olympians Who Set a European Record in Short Course Swimming (200 m breaststroke – 28 November 2001 - 7 April 2002: 2:22.90 (28 November 2001; New York, USA), 2:21.93 (14 December 2001; Antwerpen, BEL)) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Aquatics Championships (0–1–0 2002 Berlin SWM silver: 200 m breaststroke) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Swimming Championships (25 m) (5–2–4 1996 Rostock bronze: 200 m breaststroke; 1998 Sheffield bronze: 200 m breaststroke; 1999 Lisboa gold: 200 m breaststroke; 2001 Antwerpen gold: 100 m breaststroke and 200 m breaststroke; 2002 Riesa bronze: 200 m breaststroke; 2003 Dublin silver: 200 m breaststroke; 2004 Wien gold: 200 m breaststroke; 2005 Trieste gold: 200 m breaststroke; 2006 Helsinki silver: 200 m breaststroke; 2007 Debrecen bronze: 200 m breaststroke) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Aquatics Championships (0–1–0 2005 Montréal SWI silver: 200 m breaststroke)

name: Kirk Reynolds
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (1–1–0 1995 Mar del Plata SHO gold: double trap team, silver: double trap) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (0–1–0 2006 Melbourne SHO silver: trap/pairs)

name: Zhang Zaojiu
description: Zhang Zaojiu was a race walker from Shanghai, a stronghold of the sport in pre-World War II China. In 1935, when race walking appeared on the program of the national athletics championships he placed second behind Cai Zhengyi. However, of five entrants only two finished the race. During the long trip to the 1936 Olympics in Berlin, Chang supposedly entertained the team by playing the mandolin. Personal Best: 50kmW – unknown.

name: Charles Littlejohn
description: Charles Littlejohn was born in New Zealand and educated at Nelson Boys College, where his father was a headmaster. The family moved to Australia when Littlejohn was 15, and he eventually went to Melbourne University, from where he won a prestigious Rhodes Scholarship in 1909 and became a Rhodes Scholar at New College, Oxford. During his time at Oxford, Littlejohn became a two-time rowing Blue and was a member of the 1911 and 1912 winning crews, the latter being the race in which both boats sank. In 1912 and 1913, he was also in the New College four that won the Stewards’ Challenge Cup at Henley. In the second of those years, New College won after their German opponents, Maintzer Ruder-Verein, were disqualified for not steering properly and forcing New College off course. As a member of the New College eights, Littlejohn won a silver medal at the 1912 Olympics. During World War I, Littlejohn served as a captain in the Royal Army Medical Corps. Towards the end of 1915 he was wounded in France before returning to action in Salonika and France again. Littlejohn was awarded the Military Cross (MC) and Croix du Guerre, and in 1946 was honoured with the CBE. Littlejohn left Oxford with a diploma in anthropology, with distinction. He became a surgeon and worked at Bart’s Hospital in London until returning to Australia after the War. He was a surgeon at the Melbourne Children’s Hospital between 1921-24 and then at the Royal Melbourne Hospital until 1933, when he was made the hospital’s honorary orthopedic surgeon. A keen all-round sportsman, Littlejohn enjoyed playing tennis and golf in his spare time, and during his time at Bart’s was a member of their rugby first XV.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Competed in the Boat Race (1911 Oxford (won), 1912 Oxford (won)) Listed in Olympians Who Were Awarded a Rhodes Scholarship (1909 Rhodes Scholar – New College)

name: Maurice Carlton
description: Personal Best: 100 – 10.8 (1936).

name: Hermenegildo García
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (2–0–0 1989 Duisburg FEN gold: foil team; 1993 Buffalo FEN gold: foil team) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Central American and Caribbean Games (1–0–0 1990 Ciudad de México FEN gold: foil team)

name: Petra Born
description: West German ice dancer Petra Born skated with Rainer Schönborn from 1981-85 and competed regularly both at the Europeans and the Worlds. In 1985 they had their best season, placing fifth at the Worlds and winning a European bronze medal. At the 1984 Sarajevo Winter Olympics they finished ninth. In 1981 and 1982 the couple was runner-up at the West German nationals and from 1983-85 they won three national titles in a row. Born later worked as an anesthesiologist at the St. Josefs Clinic in Neunkirchen-Kohlhof, stayed unmarried, and had a son.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Figure Skating Championships (0–0–1 1985 Göteborg bronze: ice dancing)

name: Chris Thorpe
description: Chris Thorpe has competed in four Winter Olympics as a luger, partnering Gordy Sheer three times, and the two improved each time, placing 12th at the 1992 Albertville Games, 5th at the 1994 Lillehammer Games, and winning a silver medal in Nagano in 1998. The silver medal was the first Olympic medal ever won by a US luger. Thorpe and Sheer also won two silver medals at the 1995 and 1996 World Championships and won the season World Cup in 1997. Sheer retired after the 1998 Winter Olympics, and Thorpe combined with Clay Ives , who had previously competed for Canada, and the two won a bronze medal at the 2002 Winter Olympics. Thorpe retired from luge after the 2002 Winter Olympics and became a motivational speaker.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Luge Championships (0–2–0 1995 Lillehammer silver: doubles; 1996 Altenberg silver: doubles)

name: Julio Domínguez
description: Julio Domínguez was a Spanish long-distance runner who came from Madrid. Domínguez ran in the cross-country race at the 1920 Antwerpen Olympics. He was the only Spaniard in the race, finishing in 25th place out of the 42 athletes who completed the course.

name: Vijitha Amerasekera
description: Personal Best: JT – 56.84 (1994).

name: Pentti Kahma
description: Personal Best: DT – 66.82 (1975).
special_notes: Brother of Markus Kahma Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Athletics Championships (1–0–0 1974 Roma gold: discus throw)

name: Cyrus Beasley
description: Cyrus Beasley rowed single sculls at the 1996 Atlanta Olympics. Beasley graduated from Emory University. He also competed at the World Championships consecutively from 1994-98, in the quad in 1994 and 1997, the pair in 1998, and the singles in 1995. Beasley won a silver medal in the single sculls at the 1995 Pan American Games. He was on the US rowing team from 1994-2000. After his rowing career ended, Beasley worked for Resolute Racing Shells as a builder and designer. In 2003 he joined Sweenor Builders as a lead carpenter. In 2008 he left to start his own company, Beasley Woodworks, in southern Rhode Island.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–1–0 1995 Mar del Plata ROW silver: single sculls)

name: Ian Johnston
description: Ian Johnston was born in Dublin, Ireland, but moved to Canada after World War II. He settled in British Columbia and became active in the local field hockey scene, joining Grasshoppers H.C. He was eventually selected for the Canadian national side, joining in 1962. He was a member of the team that travelled to the 1964 Tokyo Olympics, where Canada lost six of its seven classification round matches and placed joint-13th out of 15 squads overall. The Canadians had better luck at the 1967 Pan American Games, where they placed fourth after losing the bronze medal match against the United States; Johnston served as co-captain of the team. By then nearing the age of 40, Johnston retired from active competition shortly thereafter.

name: Julien Robert
special_notes: Husband (divorced) of Florence Baverel-Robert Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Biathlon Championships (1–0–1 2001 Pokljuka gold: 4×7.5 km relay; 2004 Oberhof bronze: 4×7.5 km relay)

name: Walter March
description: Walter and Werner March were brothers and the sons of Otto March, who built the German Stadium in Berlin of 1913, where the proposed 1916 Olympics were to have taken place. Walter stood in his brother’s during their lifetime. Both brothers were architects and won the 1936 competition for the construction of the Berlin sports forum. Model, ground plan, and photos were his 1928 entry for the art competitions. Construction began after the Reichstag had paid a first installment of one million RMs. A part of the dormitory for female students and the connecting tunnel were completed. The second phase of construction fell victim to the government’s savings plans. After 1933 the construction of the forum was finalized, although the university was dissolved. In fall 1933, the brothers were awarded the contract to build the Reichssportfeld and the Olympic Stadium for 1936. Walter March worked in the 1920s at times in the US with Frank Lloyd Wright and took US citizenship in 1931. There he worked on numerous buildings in Greater New York. He also designed ceramics, furniture and other wood and metal works. While Walter March went to the US, Werner collaborated with the Nazis and joined the party in 1933. Walter March later became a founding member of the Carl-Diem-Institute (1964). Walter March is not mentioned in many contemporary German sources (for instance the 1936 art catalog). His participation is noted, however, in the Official Report and in the 1937 Revue Olympique. It can only be assumed that this was due to his emigration to the United States.
special_notes: Brother of Werner March

name: Mark Pharaoh
description: Mark Pharaoh was the 1949 AAA junior discus champion at the age of 18 but could not defend his title the following year because the Championships took place 11 days after his 19th birthday, which put him beyond the upper age limit. Pharaoh went on to study science at Manchester University before later becoming a civil engineer. His athletics career was mentored by the legendary British athletics coach John Le Masurier, the man who guided Mary Rand to her Olympic gold. Pharaoh finished fourth in the senior AAA discus in 1951 with a UK best 43.07. However, he went on to win four of the five titles between 1952-56, and finished second to Hungary’s four-time Olympian, Ferenc Klics in 1954. Pharaoh also finished third in the AAA shot in 1953 and 1954, and second in 1955. Internationally, Pharaoh competed in the discus at the 1952 Olympics and the following year won gold in the discus, and silver in both the shot and hammer at the Summer International University Sports Week (forerunner of the Universiade). At the 1954 British Empire and Commonwealth Games in Vancouver, Pharaoh won a discus bronze medal. He also finished fifth in the shot and tenth in the hammer. A few weeks later, at the European Championships in Bern, Pharaoh finished 18th in the shot, and 10th in the discus. A second Olympic selection followed in 1956 and he finished fourth in the discus with a personal best of 54.27. He failed to win a medal by just 13 cm, behind three Americans. His fourth place was the best by a Briton since George Stuart Robertson’s fourth in 1896, and a position not bettered by a British discus thrower through 2016. Personal Best: DT – 54.27 (1956).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (0–0–1 1954 Vancouver ATH bronze: discus throw (competed for England))

name: Ahmed Mohamed Hassanein
description: Ahmed Hassanein’s father was a professor at Al-Azhar University and a confidant of many important Egyptian political figures. After graduating from Oxford University, Ahmed held several important positions under King Fuad I and taught his son, the future Farouk of Egypt, how to speak Arabic in addition to his native Turkish. During the 1920s he was a prolific international fencer and competed in two Summer Olympics: he was eliminated in the opening round of the individual foil competition and the quarter-finals of the individual épée event in 1920, but did not win a single bout in the individual épée tournament in 1924. A man of many talents, Hassanein also undertook several scientific studies and explorations in the Libyan Desert during this period. Among the most famous of his reports was his discovery of previously unknown oases that helped pave the way for new trade routes to through the Sahara, and his findings were reported in National Geographic Magazine (complete with a detailed map) and eventually became the subject of their book “The Lost Oasis.” For his work in the region, which included a detailed cultural history of the Senussi people and thousands of photographs, he received the Gold Medal of the British Royal Geographical Society in 1924. He remained a close confidant of the King and served in the higher echelons of the court for many years until he died in a car accident on the Qasr al-Nil Bridge in February 1946.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Died in Motor Vehicle Accidents (Boat/Car/Motorcycle/Train) (Died in an accident with the British military presence on the Qasr al-Nil bridge.)

name: Anne-Lise Parisien
description: Anne-Lise Parisien came from a skiing family, as her sister Julie, and brother Rob, also competed in Alpine skiing for the US at the Olympics. Anne-Lise won two Nor-Am races in 1992 and 1993, and won her first World Cup points shortly before the Lillehammer Olympics. Her best event was giant slalom, the one event in which she competed at the Olympics. She dominated junior skiing in the US, winning GS and super-G at the 1988 J-II Championships, and at the 1991 J-I Championships, she won two gold medals, two silvers, and a bronze.
special_notes: Sister of Julie Parisien Sister of Rob Parisien

name: Eric Jackson
description: Eric “EJ” Jackson competed in slalom kayak at the 1992 Barcelona Olympics. He never competed again at the Olympics but turned to freestyle kayaking, or playboating, at which he won the World Championship four times – in 1993, 2001, 2005, and 2007, finishing second in 2009. He was given the Everest Award in 2005 and 2007, given to the top freestyler kayaker in the world. Jackson worked for many years for canoe manufacturers as a kayak designer, but in 2003 founded his own company Jackson Kayak.

name: Zuleidis Ortiz
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (2–1–0 1995 Mar del Plata FEN silver: épée team; 1999 Winnipeg FEN gold: épée team; 2003 Santo Domingo FEN gold: épée team) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Fencing Championships (0–2–0 1997 Cape Town silver: épée; 1998 La Chaux-de-Fonds silver: épée team) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Central American and Caribbean Games (3–0–1 1998 Maracaibo FEN gold: épée team, bronze: épée; 2006 Cartagena de Indias FEN gold: épée and épée team)

name: Jenő Uhlyárik
description: Starting in 1911 Jenő Uhlyárik fenced with BBTE. In 1923 he moved to MOVE BSE and one year later to Wesselényi Vivó Klub. Uhlyárik competed both in sabre and foil, but achieved his best results in sabre. Between 1924 and 1929 he competed seven times with the Hungarian national team. He was a member of the Hungarian sabre team at the 1924 Paris Olympics, winning a silver medal. His best individual result came in placing second at the 1925 European Championship in Oostende. He did not qualify for the 1928 Amsterdam Olympics, so in 1929 he resigned from the national team and retired from active sports in 1930. Prior to World War II, Uhlyárik served as secretary-general of the Hungarian Fencing Association, starting in 1934. He was a qualified technical draftsman, but then became a professional soldier. He served in the artillery, and eventually retired as a colonel.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Fencing Championships (0–1–0 1925 Oostende silver: sabre)

name: Anthony Jahnke
description: Anthony Jahnke was born in Poland. It is not known exactly when he came to the US or became a citizen, but it is known he was a US citizen in 1917. It is possible he was still a Polish citizen in 1904. Jahnke competed in the three individual all-around turnverein events in 1904, representing the Central Turnverein of Chicago.

name: Henri Louette
description: Henri Louette was born in Belgium but his family moved to Chambly-Vercheres, Québec in 1909, where he learned to play hockey. He returned to Belgium in the early 1920s, skating with Le Puck Antwerpen and Club des Patineurs de Bruxelles. A center, Louette competed at the 1924 Chamonix Winter Olympics and the 1923 European Championships.

name: Kurt Liederer
description: Kurt Liederer was an Austrian diver who participated in the 1952 Helsinki Olympics, He finished 27th in the platform event. Domestically, he represented ASV Wien (Vienna). His nephew Anton participated in the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics in Modern Pentathlon.
special_notes: Uncle of Anton Liederer

name: András Balczó
description: Hungarian András Balczó was the winner of a record five individual and five team titles in the modern pentathlon at the World Championships, winning the individual championship consecutively from 1963-1969 (it is not held in Olympic years). After placing fourth at the 1960 Olympics, Balczó won team gold and individual silver medals in 1968 and then, in 1972, he won the individual title and a silver medal in the team event for a total of five Olympic medals (three gold, two silver). Although the reigning world champion, he did not compete in the 1964 Games but his overall record is the greatest of any modern pentathlete. His best event was cross-country running. Balczó’s career was as a typewriter mechanic.
special_notes: Husband of Mónika Császár Brother-in-law of Katalin Balczó

name: Eamon Sullivan
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Set a World Record in Long Course Swimming (50 m freestyle – 17 February 2008 - 23 March 2008 and 27 March 2008 - 26 April 2009: 21.56 (17 February 2008; Sydney, AUS), 21.41 (27 March 2008; Sydney, AUS), 21.28 (28 March 2008; Sydney, AUS); 100 m freestyle – 11 August 2008 - 30 July 2009: 47.24 (11 August 2008; Beijing, CHN), 47.05 (13 August 2008; Beijing, CHN)) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Pan Pacific Swimming Championships (0–2–2 2006 Victoria silver: 4×100 m freestyle relay, bronze: 100 m freestyle and 4×100 m medley relay; 2010 Irvine silver: 4×100 m freestyle relay) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Aquatics Championships (2–0–1 2007 Melbourne SWI gold: 4×100 m medley relay, bronze: 100 m freestyle; 2011 Shanghai SWI gold: 4×100 m freestyle relay) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Short-Course Swimming Championships (25 m) (1–0–0 2008 Manchester gold: 4×100 m medley relay (swam in heats only)) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (3–1–1 2006 Melbourne SWI gold: 4×100 m medley, silver: 4×100 m freestyle; 2010 Delhi SWI gold: 4×100 m freestyle and 4×100 m medley, bronze: 100 m freestyle)

name: Ludwig Hemauer
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Shooting Championships (0–1–2 1962 Al-Qahira bronze: 50 m free pistol and 50 m free pistol team; 1966 Wiesbaden silver: 50 m free pistol team)

name: Ismail Abdallah
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Mediterranean Games (2–2–3 1955 Barcelona GYM silver: horizontal bar, bronze: team (competed for Egypt); 1959 Beirut GYM gold: horizontal bar and team, silver: all-around, bronze: parallel bars and rings)

name: Rena Wang
special_notes: Sister of Iris Wang Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–1–0 2011 Guadalajara BDM silver: doubles)

name: Thomas Knorr
description: Center handball player Thomas Knorr, father of Juri Knorr, came seventh with the German team at the 1996 Atlanta Olympics. He won 83 international caps and scored 199 goals. At the 1996 European Championships, Knorr was top scorer with 41 goals, although Germany only finished sixth. Knorr played domestically with VfL Bad Schartau (1988-92, 2001-02, 2007-11), THW Kiel (1992-98), SG Flensburg-Handewitt (1998-2001), HSV Hamburg (2002-07), Preetzer TSV (2012-13), SC Magdeburg (2013-14), and HSG Ostsee (since 2014). He helped Kiel win the German national title four times in 1994-96 and 1998, and the German Cup and EHF Cup, both in 1998. He also won the European Cup Winners’ Cup in 2001 with Flensburg-Handewitt and in 2007 with Hamburg. Knorr later turned to coaching.
special_notes: Father of Juri Knorr

name: Cindy Werley
description: Cindy Werley played hockey (field) in college at the University of North Carolina, leading that team to two NCAA Championships. Werley played on the 1996 Olympic team while she was a student at UNC, from which she graduated in 1998. In 1996 and 1997 she was ACC Player of the Year. Werley also won silver medals at the 1995 and 1999 Pan American Games, and added a bronze medal at the 1995 Champions Trophy. Werley, later Cindy Baugh, coached at UNC, Louisville, and Duke as an assistant, but she later had children and stepped back to spend more time with them. She had her #13 retired at UNC in a ceremony at halftime of a UNC basketball game.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–2–0 1995 Mar del Plata HOK silver; 1999 Winnipeg HOK silver)

name: Anis Chedli
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Mediterranean Games (0–1–1 2001 Tunis JUD bronze: heavyweight +100 kg; 2009 Pescara JUD silver: heavyweight +100 kg)

name: Franz Frauneder
description: Rower Franz Frauneder was a member of the Austrian coxed fours crew at the 1948 London Olympics. They qualified for the quarter-finals but were eliminated by Switzerland. Domestically, the crew rowed with RV Albatros Klagenfurt.

name: Joe Bottom
description: While at Southern Call, Joe Bottom won three NCAA freestyle titles in the 1974-76 50 yard freestyle and the 1974 100 yard freestyle, also winning four relay titles with the Trojans. He won nine US titles between 1974-80. Bottom graduated from USC with a degree in electrical engineering. Bottom won silver in the 100 butterfly at the 1973 World Championships, adding golds in the 4×100 freestyle and medley relays. Bottom won the 100 fly again at the 1978 Worlds, also winning again in the medley relay. At a 1977 dual meet against East Germany in East Berlin, Bottom broke one of the most revered swimming world records, recording 54.18 in the 100 fly to better Mark Spitz’s record from the 1972 Olympics. At that meet Bottom also swam on the US team that broke the 4×100 freestyle relay world record. Bottom was inducted into the International Swimming Hall of Fame in 2006 and the USC Athletic Hall of Fame in 2007. He later became a management consultant, working with Accenture’s Marketing Sciences Practice.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Set a World Record in Long Course Swimming (100 m butterfly – 27 August 1977 - 11 April 1980: 54.18 (27 August 1977; Ost-Berlin, GDR); 4×100 m freestyle relay – 1 September 1974 - 25 July 1975 and 28 August 1977 - 22 August 1978: 3:25.17 (1 September 1974; Concord, USA), 3:21.11 (28 August 1977; Ost-Berlin, GDR); 4×100 m medley relay – 22 July 1976 - 22 July 1976: 3:47.28 (22 July 1976; Montréal, CAN)) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Aquatics Championships (7–1–0 1973 Belgrade SWI gold: 4×100 m freestyle relay and 4×100 m medley relay, silver: 100 m butterfly; 1975 Cali SWI gold: 4×100 m freestyle relay (swam in heats only) and 4×100 m medley relay (swam in heats only); 1978 West Berlin SWI gold: 100 m butterfly, 4×100 m freestyle relay (swam in heats only), and 4×100 m medley relay)

name: Peter Zupanc
description: Personal Best: JT – 78.60 (2004).

name: Cláudio Bertolino
description: Personal Best: 20kmW – 1-22:14t (1994).

name: Ann-Kathrin Linsenhoff
description: Ann-Kathrin Linsenhoff, the daughter of Liselott Linsenhoff, first came to notice as a rider when she won a silver at the 1981 German Youth Championships and the 1981 European Youth Championship with her team, and also placing third in the single dressage event that year. Between 1987 and 1990 she was a runner-up all four years at the German Championships, and also won the 1987 European Champion with her German team, placing second in the individual event. After winning a team gold medal at the 1988 Olympics, she defended the European title in the team in 1989, and in 1990 won a World Championship, again in the team event. After the birth of her son (1992) and her daughter (2001) she again rode on a World Team Champion in 2002. She stopped competing in 2007 for health reasons. A veterinary doctor, she has since then taken over several positions in sports administration and health organizations. She owns a foundation under the aegis of UNICEF (her horses are now surnamed Unicef), which receives all sponsorship and sale money from her horses. In January 2008 she became the first woman to be named to the presidental chair of Deutsche Sporthilfe, resigning in September 2008. In April 2008 she was named a Deputy Vice President of UNICEF. She also led the Linsenhoff-Stiftung.
special_notes: Daughter of Liselott Linsenhoff

name: Umberto Nannini
description: Umberto Nannini was an Italian military and aviation pilot who competed in the gliding exhibition at the 1936 Berlin Olympics. His most famous feat dates back to 1933 when he was part of the legendary Crociera del Decennale commanded by General Italo Balbo. From 1 July to 12 August, 25 seaplanes carrying 115 people flew round-trip from Orbetello on the Mediterranean Sea to the Chicago World’s Fair with legs in Amsterdam, Londonderry, Reykjavik, Cartwright, Shediac, and Montréal, ending on Lake Michigan and finally New York. Nannini was in charge of the squadron (one of eight in total) called Rossa Stellata (Red Star). From Chicago the entire squadron flew to New York with an escort of 36 US planes, where they were given a warm welcome on Broadway as millions of people watched the parade. US President Franklin D. Roosevelt invited General Balbo and all his men to lunch. On 25 July the group returned via Shediac, Shoal Harbour, Ponta Delgada, and Lisboa, landing at the seaplane base of Ostia on 12 August, and ending what The Times described as “the greatest exploit in the history of the Air Force.” During World War II, Nannini was for some years at the Budapest legation and when he was reached by the news of the armistice (8 September 1943), he immediately worked to protect and defend Italian interests, safeguarding thousands of remaining soldiers involved in the events of the armistice. In the 1960s, Nannini co-founded the Associazione Trasvolatori Atlantici.

name: Tom Trethewey
description: Tom Trethewey swam at Mt. Lebanon High School in Pittsburgh and then at Indiana University. He was 1965 NCAA Champion in the 200 yard breaststroke, and swam on the winning Indiana medley relay team in 1965. Trethewey won the 1965 AAU title outdoors in the 100 metre breaststroke. After college Trethewey joined the US Navy and became a fighter pilot, with he and his wife settling in Summerville, South Carolina after his Navy retirement.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (1–0–0 1965 Budapest SWI gold: 4×100 m medley relay)

name: Hans Wetterström
description: Hans Wetterström had the following podium finishes at the Flatwater World Championships: 1st 1948 K4 1000 m (with Hans Berglund, Lennart Klingström, and Gunnar Åkerlund), 1st 1950 K2 10000 m (with Gunnar Åkerlund), 2nd 1950 K4 1000 m (with Gunnar Åkerlund, Sven-Olov Sjödelius, and the non-Olympian Ebbe Frick), 2nd 1954 K4 10000 m (with Carl-Gunnar Sundin and the non-Olympians Sigvard Johansson and Rolf Fjellmann).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Canoe Sprint World Championships (2–2–0 1948 London gold: K4 1000 m; 1950 København gold: K2 10000 m, silver: K4 1000 m; 1954 Mâcon silver: K4 10000 m)

name: Kémobé Djimassal
description: Personal Best: LJ – 7.42 (1978).

name: Judit Nagy-Földing
description: Personal Best: Mar – 2-28:50 (1996).

name: Živa Dvoršak
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Mediterranean Games (0–0–1 2018 Tarragona SHO bronze: 10 m air rifle)

name: Joost Boks
description: Domestically, goalkeeper Joost Boks made his senior début for Amsterdam (AH&BC) in 1960. As one of the leading Dutch club teams in the 1960s, it won the title 1962-1966 (although the championship wasn’t held in 1963). In 1963, Boks played his first of 50 international matches with the Dutch national team. Remarkably for a goalie, he scored in one of these games, scoring a penalty stroke against Germany in a 1967 friendly match. Boks was selected for both the 1964 and 1968 Olympics. In the deciding pool stage match in Mexico 1968, a dominant Dutch side trailed Australia 0-1 when Boks attempted to save a shot. Although Boks claimed this was incorrect, he was fouled for sitting on the ball. Australia converted the subsequent penalty stroke and eliminated Boks and the Dutch from medal contention. Boks retired after the Games, pursuing a career with IBM, for which he moved to Canada in the 1970s.

name: Imre Páli
description: Imre Páli (born as Paul) won the Hungarian championship in 1936 and 1938 with the Újpest handball team. In 1936 he played two games in the Hungarian national team at the Berlin Olympics and finished fourth with the team. After the Olympics, he no longer participated in the Hungarian national team.

name: Willy Bührer
description: Personal Best: Dec – 5849 (1936).

name: Pacita Wiedel
description: Pacita Wiedel was born in Spain and moved to Germany at a young age, where she was a survivor of bombings during World War II. She came to Canada in the late 1950s, where she took up work at the Bank of Nova Scotia as a loan officer. Then known as Pacita Dumenieux, she was a highly successful member of Toronto’s Harmonie Fencing Club in the late 1950s, which mainly consisted of German-Canadians. She won the women’s foil competition in 1960 at an international tournament hosted by the Amateur Fencing League of America in Buffalo, and married clubmate, Gerry Wiedel around that same year. Pacita Wiedel was a seven-time Canadian women’s foil champion (1959–64; 1966) and runner-up on three occasions (1967–68, 1971). She also won nine provincial titles. She continued to be active in fencing throughout the 1960s and 1970s, competing at the 1966 British Empire Games, 1967 Pan American Games, and 1970 Commonwealth Games. She won three bronze medals, two in the team foil event (1967, 1970) and one in individual foil (1967). She and her husband later retired to Port Carling, Ontario.
special_notes: Wife of Gerry Wiedel Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–0–2 1967 Winnipeg FEN bronze: foil and foil team) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (0–0–1 1970 Edinburgh FEN bronze: team foil)

name: Frankie Sodano
description: Frankie Sodano boxed as a flyweight at the 1948 Olympics, after defeating Pappy Gault, later manager of the 1968 US Olympic boxing team, at the US Olympic Trials. Sodano was also 1948 AAU flyweight champion, and won the Diamond Belt tournament that year in Philadelphia. Sodano turned professional in November 1948 and fought through 1954, winning 49 fights, losing 8, with one draw, but he never received a title shot. Sodano was inducted into the South Philadelphia High School Hall of Fame in 2002.

name: Raymond Thompson
description: Raymond Thompson attended the US Naval Academy, where he was on the swim team, winning the 1933 NCAA Championship in the 50 yard freestyle. He made the 1932 Olympic team by placing second in the US Olympic Trials in the 100 metre freestyle. Thompson was President of his class at Annapolis, and later earned a master’s degree in electrical engineering from MIT. During World War II he served aboard the battleship Washington and participated in combat at Guadalcanal. His immediate post-war duty was aboard destroyers. He later settled in the Washington area, serving on the staff of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and retiring from the Navy in 1963. Thompson then joined NASA (National Aeronautics and Space Administration) where he worked as a liaison to other federal agencies, including the Department of Defense, retiring from there in 1974.

name: Ståle Sandbech

name: Debbie Miller

name: Ranieri, Conte di Campello
description: Ranieri, Count di Campello competed in eventing at the 1936 Berlin Olympics. He was the son of Count Pompeo di Campello, a senator in the Kingdom of Italy, and the Princess Guglielmina Boncompagni Ludovisi, a court lady of the Queen Elena di Savoia. Ranieri began a promising career in horse riding and was a contender at the Berlin Olympics, but he fell in the cross-country phase. During World War II Count di Campello served many roles. He was in the military office at the Italian embassy in Bucureşti and in 1941 served in Spain for military operations against Gibraltar. In the years 1942-43 he was in Russia with the Armata Italiana in Russia (ARMIR) as an officer of the Savoia Cavalleria, In Russia he fought in an operation near the city of Nikitowka, was severely wounded, and was awarded the Silver Medal of Military Valor. After the war di Campello left the Army and was a member and later President of the Italian Equestrian Federation. In the 1950s he was vice-president of the Fédération Equestrian Internationale (FEI) and a member of the council of CONI (Italian Olympic committee). From 1952 until his death Count di Campello served as mayor of Campello sul Clitunno.
special_notes: Grandfather of Ranieri Campello Listed in Olympian Members of the Nobility (Conte (Count))

name: Naoki Matsuda
description: Naoki Matsuda was educated at Maebashi Ikuei High School. In 1995 he joined the professional squad of Yokohama F. Marinos and helped them win the Japanese League championship in 1995, 2003 and 2004 as well as the Japanese Cup in 2001. In 2000 and 2002 he was elected to the Top Eleven of the Japanese League. Internationally, he played for Japan’s U-17 World Championship team in 1993 and at the 1995 U-20 World Championships. He also played in the 2000 Asian Championships which was won by his team, then played the FIFA Confederations Cup in 2001 (Japan lost the final against France by 0-1) and the FIFA World Cup in 2002 (Japan lost the eighth final against Turkey by 0-1), being considered one of the top players in Japan. In 2004 he played his last major tournament at the Asian Championships. He also was a member of the Japanese squad at the Olympics in 1996 and 2000. In 2011, shortly prior to his death, he signed a contract with Matsumoto Yamaga FC. On 2 August 2011, he collapsed during a training session due to a cardiac arrest, and passed away two days later.

name: Jean-Luc Brassard
description: A gold medalist in freestyle skiing moguls at the 1994 Winter Olympics, Jean-Luc Brassard was no stranger to victory, having won the right to be named World and Canadian Champion at the event in 1993. He began skiing at the age of eight, was named to the national team at the age of 17 and won his first World Cup race a year later. He won the Canadian title again in 1995 and the World Cup in 1996 and 1997 and was for many years the leader of the elite freestyle skiing team known as the “Quebec Air Force”. After 1999, his career began to slow and was worsened by a knee injury in 2000 that forced him to miss the 2000-2001 season. He had previously competed at the 1992 Winter Olympics, and later tried for a second medal at the event in 1998 (the year that he carried the Canadian flag in the opening ceremonies) and 2002, but never again saw the podium at the Olympics. Well known for his charity work, particularly with the French division of the Children’s Miracle Network, he was given the 2000 Gillette Sport Award for his dedication to charitable endeavors. Since his retirement, he has worked with the National Speakers Bureau.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Freestyle Ski Championships (2–1–0 1993 Altenmarkt gold: moguls; 1995 La Clusaz silver: moguls; 1997 Nagano gold: moguls)

name: Marcel Van de Perre
description: Belgian sculptor Marcel Van de Perre worked from 1938-40 in the brickyard A. Florizoone Neoceram in Nieuwport. There he led the art studio, which was specially equipped for sculpture. Two sculptures of him are still visible in public places in Nieuwport. He then became a professor at the Municipal Academy in Ghent. The motif Hockey appears in at least two sculptures.

name: Adolf Lauda
description: Adolf Lauda was an Austrian show jumper who took part in the 1956 Stockholm Equestrian Games, which could not be held at Melbourne due to Australian quarantine regulations. Halm did not finish the competition riding Schönbrunn as he fell out of the ranking after the first round. Consequently, the Austrian team also remained unplaced.

description: Rolando Mosqueira had the following podium finishes at major championships: 2nd in the 1951 Pan American Games Three-Day Event team (with Hernán Vigil, Guillermo Squella, and Mario Leuenberg).

name: William Cuthbertson
description: William Cuthbertson was Scottish amateur flyweight champion in 1920-21, British Champion in 1921, and Scottish bantamweight champion in 1922, before turning professional in 1923. Cuthbertson had 15 professional fights between 1923-27. His brothers, Andy and Peter, were both professional boxers in the later 1920s and early 1930s. After his retirement from the ring, Cuthbertson became a boxing instructor at the Carnegie Gym in Dunferrnline and at Craigflower Private School at Torryburn.

name: Dursun Ali Eğribaş
description: Dursun Ali Eğribaş started wrestling in 1947, while he was working as a janitor at the Feshane Wrestling Club in İstanbul. In addition to his bronze medal in Greco-Roman at the 1956 Melbourne Olympics, Eğribaş was the Mediterranean Games Greco-Roman flyweight champion in 1959 and won gold at the 1959 and bronze at the 1960 Balkan Games. He stopped competing in 1965 and taught wrestling at his club in Feshane, and worked in trade.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Mediterranean Games (1–0–0 1959 Beirut WRE gold: Greco-Roman flyweight -52 kg)

name: Paul Hoffman
description: Paul Hoffmann had a long career as a top-flight coxswain. He prepped at Phillips Andover and Bryanston in England, and coxed boats from those prep schools at the Henley Regatta in 1962 and 1964. In both 1968 and 1972 he was the cox for the U.S. eight at the Olympics, leading them to a silver medal in 1972. He also won a gold medal with the eight at the 1967 Pan-American Games and coxed Harvard to four straight wins at the Eastern Sprints, starting from 1965. Hoffman served in the Peace Corps for a time after college, but returned to Harvard to earn a J.D. degree in 1974 and worked as a lawyer. He also helped coach the U.S. team at the 1977 World Championships in Amsterdam.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (1–0–0 1967 Winnipeg ROW gold: eights)

name: Alexandre Foureaux
description: Primarily a road racer, Alexandre Foureaux competed in the first Tour de France in 1903, placing 16th, and rode the race again in 1904, with less success. He rode Bordeaux-Paris in 1896-97 and 1900-01, with a best placing of fifth in 1901. He also copmeted at Paris-Roubaix in 1899 and 1901, finishing sixth in 1901.

name: Ronnie Mills
description: Ronnie Mills competed for the Burford Swim Club of Fort Worth and Arlington Heights High School. His Olympic bronze medal was his major career achievement, and was accomplished only after his junior year in high school. He later swam for SMU, making All-American for three years, and won eight individual Southwest Conference championships.

name: Dave Snuggerud
description: After playing at Hopkins High School in Minnesota, right-winger Dave Snuggerud played with the Minnesota Junior North Stars of the US Hockey League, and then went to the University of Minnesota. Snuggerud would later play four seasons in the NHL with the Buffalo Sabres, San Jose Sharks, and the Philadelphia Flyers. Snuggerud represented the US at the 1988 Winter Olympics and the 1989 World Championships. He finished his pro career with a single season (1994-95) with the Minnesota Moose of the International Hockey League. Snuggerud later became a high school hockey coach, starting at Chaska High School in his native Minnesota.
